description: central panel with mottled yellow, grey, and blue ground, with blue mottled geometric forms with a half-circle near bottom center and smaller forms in rows and columns, with larger forms at bottom; central panel inset in a shadow box frame with medium-toned wood ground and grey frame edges; received in white shadow box outer frame
signed: The painting is signed and dated by the artist in the upper left corner.
text: Anwar Jalal Shemza was a Pakistani who emigrated to Britain in 1956. Produced in 1962, this work demonstrates a crystallization of the artist’s approach, after years of struggle negotiating his personal identity in a decolonizing world. Influenced by the mystical qualities of abstract artist Paul Klee, Shemza sought to fuse Islamic calligraphic structure, pattern, and geometry with the Western modernist plane. Throughout the composition, the circle (which in Islamic theology represents infinity) and square (representing man) are used as modular building blocks, capable of serial expansion. Inherent in this structure is a repetition and stacking of the Roman letters ‘B’ and ‘D’, looped with a fluidity reminiscent of Arabic calligraphy. Painted after a visit to Lahore, the textured surface is evocative of blue tiles on old city walls, while the pattern brings to mind the domes on mosques and minarets. The artist once explained, “My paintings are not only to look at but are also writings to be read.”
title: Blue Composition
